Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating gene and individual level selection to understand the evolution of self-fertilization in flowering plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Throughout the biosphere, most organisms display some sort of adaptation to reduce inbreeding. In flowering plants alone, there are a staggering number of adaptations that prevent inbreeding, yet these systems break down frequently. Mutations causing self-pollination should enjoy two major selective advantages. Mutations causing self-pollination will spread in nature either because they enjoy a gene-level transmission advantage or because they boost seed production when pollination is uncertain. No study has simultaneously tested these mechanisms and evaluated their interaction, so it is not well understood why outcross-pollination mechanisms repeatedly break down. In this project, a mutation causing self-pollination will be crossed into a typically outcross-pollinated genome and replicated field experiments will examine whether this mutation spreads because of genetic or ecological reasons.
This project will identify the mechanisms that cause evolutionary shifts to inbreeding, which imperil plant biodiversity. The project will train undergraduate and graduate students to use genetic markers to infer parentage and patterns of gene flow, which are critical tools in applied agricultural settings. Students will present their results at public outreach events coordinated by the Center for Cedar Glades Studies (CCGS) in Tennessee. The involvement of students in the process of direct outreach will communicate the principles of evolution and conservation biology to the public. The PIs will also work with science educators at the CCGS to develop a pollination ecology field exercise aimed at K-12 students to be included in the "Cedar Glades Activity Guide" published by the CCGS and used by many local science teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of self-fertilization from outcrossing is among the most common evolutionary trends in flowering plants, having occurred numerous times in almost every plant family. A major goal of this project was to evaluate the costs and benefits of a newly arising mutation that allows self-fertilization. This allowed us to examine how natural selection acts on such mutations in natural populations over multiple years. These mutations may be beneficial  if they allow seed production when pollinators and/or mates are limiting. However, they may be costly if self-fertilization results in the production of offspring with reduced fitness due to inbreeding.

One of the main intellectual merits of this project was a complete accounting of the costs and benefits of selfing mutations across a range of environments in multiple years. A significant finding was that selfing mutations may be unlikely to spread in populations, even when they increase individual seed production. This occurs because the increase in seed production resulting from self-fertilization reduces the production of high quality outcrossed offspring. These results may help explain the widespread evolutionary maintenance of outcrossing and traits preventing self-fertilization.

The broader impacts of this research included the training of 1 PhD student, 1 MS student and four undergraduate researchers (3 female and 3 male, including one student from an underrepresented minority group). The grant research has resulted in three published papers and 10 presentations at national meetings. Results of this research were also disseminated via outreach activities through Middle Tennessee State University's Center for Cedar Glade Studies. This included presentations to the members of the public, as well as state and federal agencies at the annual Elsie Quarterman cedar glade festival research roundtable at Cedars of Lebanon State Park, Lebanon, TN.
